thread.title: Social media showcases what it means to #DressLikeAWoman
thread.title_full: Social media showcases what it means to #DressLikeAWoman

author: Mary Bowerman , USA TODAY Network
title: Social media showcases what it means to #DressLikeAWoman
text:
A female police officer.   (Photo: Darrin Klimek, Getty Images) 
President Trump’s critics took to Twitter on Friday to mock a report that suggested Trump prefers his female employees to "dress like women.”
In response to the unverified Axios report, which cites an unnamed source , women and men alike tweeted photos of women wearing a number of different outfits with the hashtag #DressLikeAWoman.
The overwhelming message on social media: In this day and age, women dress however they please in the U.S.
Here's a look at some of the responses on Twitter:
Women wear astronaut gear. 
#DressLikeAWomen Joan Higginbottom - engineer and astronaut https://t.co/RMlcHeiK0E pic.twitter.com/vUL4JWhSlc 
— Teacher Dude (@teacherdude) February 3, 2017 And sometimes hold snakes. 
Biologists get the best accessories #DressLikeAWomen pic.twitter.com/EnFBJfP4vg 
— Janet Ng (@janetngbio) February 3, 2017 Occasionally, women wear firefighter gear. 
Here I am...just following policy. #DressLikeAWomen #dresslikeawoman pic.twitter.com/RwV4dVV51y 
— *Karen* (@KarenKnowsStuff) February 3, 2017 And women know that safety always comes first. 
My name is Clara & I work on the @ATLASexperiment at @CERN . I'm an #actuallivingscientist . I #DressLikeAWomen at work - hardhat & dosimeter. pic.twitter.com/xpu3CcCkGd 
— Clara Nellist (@claranellist) February 3, 2017 This is how I #DressLikeAWomen pic.twitter.com/Sw8eX4WASr 
— MedRoyalty (@MedRoyalty) February 3, 2017
